Questions: 1. The term "Art" is derived from the Latin word Ars, which means _______.
DESCRIPTION A: Beauty is the result of some art, not the etymological root.
DESCRIPTION B: Ability or Skill as art was synonymous with "craftmanship" and technical mastery.
DESCRIPTION C: Creativity is a modern prerequisite but not the literal Latin meaning.
DESCRIPTION D: Decoration is a specific function, not the definition.

Questions: 2. According to Plato, what is the primary purpose of art in relation to the world?
A: To bring life into harmony with the beauty of the world.
C: To provide a source of income for the state.
D: To replicate nature exactly as it is.
DESCRIPTION A: Plato viewed art as a bridge to understanding universal beauty.
DESCRIPTION B: A 20th-century concept.
DESCRIPTION C: He did not view art as a primary economic tool.
DESCRIPTION D: It refers to Mimesis, but Plato actually criticized art for being a "copy of a copy."

Questions: 3. A designer uses a monochromatic color scheme for a small living room. Evaluate the effectiveness of this choice.
A: Ineffective, because it makes the room look cluttered.
B: Effective, because it is the cheapest way to paint.
C: Ineffective, because it lacks variety entirely.
D: Effective, as it creates a sense of unity and can make a space feel larger.
DESCRIPTION A: It is the opposite of what monochromatic does
DESCRIPTION B: Price does not dictate design principles.
DESCRIPTION C: Variety is achieved through value (tints/shades), not just different hues.
DESCRIPTION D: Single-hue schemes reduce visual "noise," creating an expansive, cohesive feel.

Questions: 4. Which element of art refers to the surface quality or feel of an object?
DESCRIPTION A: Texture is the perceived or actual tactile quality.
DESCRIPTION B: Value is lightness/darkness.
DESCRIPTION C: Option C is wrong: Form is 3D volume.
DESCRIPTION D: Space is the area around objects.

Questions: 5. In a painting where a small bright red circle is placed in a field of dull grey, which principle is being utilized?
DESCRIPTION A: Rhythm requires repetition.
DESCRIPTION B: Contrast in color and intensity creates a focal point.
DESCRIPTION C: Proportion deals with size relationships.
DESCRIPTION D: Symmetrical Balance would require a mirrored arrangement.

Questions: 6. To create a Formal and Stable atmosphere in a government building's facade, which type of balance is most appropriate?
DESCRIPTION A: Asymmetrical is more dynamic and informal.
DESCRIPTION B: Symmetry conveys order, authority, and permanence.
DESCRIPTION C: Radial is circular and focuses on a center point, which is less common for "stability" in facades.
DESCRIPTION D: Discordant refers to a lack of harmony or clashing elements, which would create a feeling of unease rather than stability.

Questions: 7. What is the primary difference between Egyptian art and Greek art in terms of depicting the human body?
A: Egyptians used perspective; Greeks used flat patterns.
B: Greeks only used wood; Egyptians only used stone.
C: Egyptians prioritized symbolic "frontality"; Greeks prioritized "naturalism" and movement.
D: Both are identical in their use of proportions.
DESCRIPTION A: It is reversed to option C.
DESCRIPTION B: It is historically inaccurate as both used marble and bronze.
DESCRIPTION C: Egyptians followed rigid canons to ensure "completeness" for the afterlife, while Greeks studied anatomy to depict the "ideal" living human.

Questions: 8. Which historical period is characterized by the use of "chiaroscuro" and a focus on dramatic light and shadow?
DESCRIPTION A: Baroque era (17th century) used high-contrast lighting to create emotional depth and drama.
DESCRIPTION B: Renaissance focused on balance and perspective.
DESCRIPTION C: Neoclassical prioritized clean lines and Greek ideals.
DESCRIPTION D: Impressionism focused on light and color without heavy shadows.

Questions: 9. What is the primary difference between Egyptian art and Greek art in terms of depicting the human body?
A: Egyptians prioritized symbolic "frontality"; Greeks prioritized "naturalism" and movement.
B: Egyptians used perspective; Greeks used flat patterns.
C: Greeks only used wood; Egyptians only used stone.
D: Both are identical in their use of proportions.
DESCRIPTION A: Egyptians followed rigid canons to ensure completeness for the afterlife, while Greeks studied anatomy to depict the "ideal" living human.
DESCRIPTION B: It is reversed to option A.
DESCRIPTION C: It is historically inaccurate as both used marble and bronze.

Questions: 10. In interior design, the "Golden Ratio" is most frequently applied to _______.
B: The spatial arrangement and proportions of furniture to a room.
C: The number of light bulbs used.
D: The thickness of the paint on the walls.
DESCRIPTION A: Financial metrics have nothing to do with aesthetic proportions.
DESCRIPTION B: The Golden Ratio (1:1.618) helps create layouts that are naturally pleasing to the human eye.
DESCRIPTION C: Technical metrics that have nothing to do with aesthetic proportions.
DESCRIPTION D: Technical metrics that have nothing to do with aesthetic proportions.

Questions: 11. A homeowner has a very narrow hallway. To make the space feel wider using Color Theory, which action should they take?
A: Paint the walls a dark, warm red.
B: Paint the walls a light, cool blue.
C: Paint the floor and ceiling black.
D: Paint the walls a light, cool blue.
DESCRIPTION A: Warm colors are advancing and would make the hallway feel tighter.
DESCRIPTION B: The color would create a tunnel effect.
DESCRIPTION C: Vertical stripes make a room feel taller, not wider.
DESCRIPTION D: Light, cool colors are receding colors; they visually push walls away, making a space feel larger.

Questions: 12. Which of the following is a Secondary Color?
DESCRIPTION A: Green is made by mixing two primary colors (Yellow + Blue).
DESCRIPTION B: Red is a primary color.
DESCRIPTION C: Yellow is a primary color.
DESCRIPTION D: Blue is a primary color.

Questions: 13. How does Asymmetrical Balance achieve equilibrium in a visual composition?
A: By mirroring identical elements on both sides of a center line.
B: By placing all heavy objects at the bottom of the canvas.
C: By using different elements with equal visual weight.
D: By using only one color throughout the entire piece.
DESCRIPTION A: It is Formal/Symmetrical balance.
DESCRIPTION B: It is a type of gravity-based composition but not balance
DESCRIPTION C: Visual weight can be balanced by placing a large dull object against a small bright one.
DESCRIPTION D: It refers to harmony or unity.

Questions: 14. An artist wants to create a feeling of Chaos and Energy in a digital painting. Which type of rhythm is most effective?
DESCRIPTION A: It is too predictable and calming.
DESCRIPTION B: It shows a steady increase or decrease (like a staircase).
DESCRIPTION C: Random rhythm lacks a predictable pattern, which creates the feeling of spontaneity and disorder.
DESCRIPTION D: It is too predictable and calming.

Questions: 15. The term Value in visual arts refers to ________.
A: The price of the artwork at an auction.
B: The lightness or darkness of a color.
C: The historical importance of the artist.
D: The physical weight of the materials used.
DESCRIPTION A: It refers to Market Value
DESCRIPTION B: Value is used to create the illusion of 3D form on a flat surface.
DESCRIPTION C: It refers to Provenance or Significance
DESCRIPTION D: It refers to Physical Mass.

Questions: 16. Why is unity often described as the most important principle of design?
A: Because it prevents the viewer from looking at the art for too long.
B: Because it allows the artist to use as many colors as possible.
C: Because it ensures that all elements work together to create a singular, cohesive message.
D: Because it is the only principle that uses lines.
DESCRIPTION A: Good design usually keeps the viewer's attention.
DESCRIPTION B: It refers to Variety, which can actually destroy unity if not balanced.
DESCRIPTION C: Without unity, a design feels like a collection of random parts rather than a finished whole.
DESCRIPTION D: It is variety, which is the opposite of unity.

Questions: 17. A sculpture is made entirely of recycled plastic bottles to comment on environmental waste. This is an example of art's ______ function.
DESCRIPTION A: Personal is for self-expression.
DESCRIPTION B: Art that addresses collective human concerns, politics, or environmental issues serves a social function.
DESCRIPTION C: Physical is for utility.
DESCRIPTION D: Economic is not a standard functional category of art.

Questions: 18. In painting, Tempera is a medium that typically uses what substance as a binder for the pigment?
DESCRIPTION A: Egg tempera was the primary medium for panel painting before the invention of oil paint.
DESCRIPTION B: Linseed Oil is for Oil paint.
DESCRIPTION C: Plaster is for Fresco.
DESCRIPTION D: Gum Arabic is for Watercolor.

Questions: 19. If an artist wants to create a sculpture that is light, durable, and can be mass-produced through a mold, which medium is most appropriate?
DESCRIPTION A: Marble is heavy and must be carved.
DESCRIPTION B: Bronze is very heavy and expensive.
DESCRIPTION C: Terracotta is fragile and prone to breaking.
DESCRIPTION D: Resin is lightweight and ideal for industrial molding and reproduction

Questions: 20. How does Impressionism differ from Realism?
A: Impressionism focuses on exact details; Realism focuses on light.
B: Impressionism captures a fleeting moment of light; Realism depicts the "truth" of everyday life.
C: Realism uses bright neon colors; Impressionism uses only black and white.
D: Both movements are identical in style but occurred in different centuries.
DESCRIPTION A: Impressionists cared about the optical effects of light at a specific moment, while Realists aimed to show the unvarnished, often gritty reality of social conditions.
DESCRIPTION B: Impressionists cared about the atmosphere and optics; Realists cared about the social conditions of the working class.
DESCRIPTION C: Realism typically uses earthy, natural tones to reflect the real world. Impressionism is famous for its bright, vibrant color palettes, not black and white.
DESCRIPTION D: It is historically false.

Questions: 21. Which art movement is famous for fragmenting objects into geometric shapes and showing multiple viewpoints at once?
DESCRIPTION A: Cubism broke objects into planes to show them from several angles simultaneously.
DESCRIPTION B: Surrealism deals with dreams/subconscious
DESCRIPTION C: Pop Art deals with consumer culture.
DESCRIPTION D: Fauvism deals with wild colors.

Questions: 22. What is the result of adding white to a pure hue?
DESCRIPTION A: Adding black creates a shade.
DESCRIPTION B: A neutral refers to colors like brown/beige.
DESCRIPTION C: Adding grey creates a tone.
DESCRIPTION D: A tint increases the lightness of a color

Questions: 23. Which of the following is an example of Radial Balance?
A: A portrait where the face is in the exact center.
B: A landscape with a large tree on the left and a small bush on the right.
C: A rose window in a cathedral where all elements radiate from the center.
D: A pattern of stripes on a shirt.
DESCRIPTION A: It is Formal/Symmetrical.
DESCRIPTION B: It is Asymmetrical.
DESCRIPTION C: Radial balance moves outward from a central focal point like a wheel.
DESCRIPTION D: It is Repetition/Rhythm.

Questions: 24. The intensity or saturation of a color refers to its _________.
DESCRIPTION A: Lightness is value.
DESCRIPTION B: Name is Hue.
DESCRIPTION C: Temperature is Warmth/Coolness.
DESCRIPTION D: Intensity describes how pure or vivid a color is versus how washed out it is.

Questions: 25. If you want to create Emphasis in a black-and-white photograph, what is the most effective method?
A: Introducing a single element in a vibrant color.
B: Making everything the same shade of grey.
C: Taking the photo in total darkness.
DESCRIPTION A: Contrast—whether through color, size, or shape—is the fastest way to create a focal point.
DESCRIPTION B: It creates unity but lacks emphasis.
DESCRIPTION C: Technical errors that don't guarantee emphasis.
DESCRIPTION D: Styles that don't guarantee emphasis

Questions: 26. Which branch of art is concerned with the design of buildings and structures?
DESCRIPTION A: Architecture is the primary art form of creating habitable spaces.
DESCRIPTION B: Interior Design is the inside.
DESCRIPTION C: Landscape Gardening is indoor plants.
DESCRIPTION D: Urban Planning is the layout of cities.

Questions: 27. Which indigenous weaving tradition from the T'boli people uses abaca fibers and is often called Dream Weaving?
DESCRIPTION A: Piña is made from pineapple fibers.
DESCRIPTION B: T'nalak designs are said to be communicated to the weavers in their dreams by the spirit Fu Dalu.
DESCRIPTION C: Inabel is an Ilocano weaving tradition.
DESCRIPTION D: Banig is a mat, not specifically abaca weaving.

Questions: 28. Who is known as the Father of Modern Philippine Painting for introducing bold strokes and distorted figures?
DESCRIPTION A: Edades challenged the "Amorsolo School" of beauty by introducing the "Triumvirate" and modernism.
DESCRIPTION B: Fernando Amorsolo is the master of traditional backlighting.
DESCRIPTION C: Vicente Manansala is a cubist.
DESCRIPTION D: Carlos "Botong" Francisco is a muralist.

Questions: 29. Who is the philosopher that viewed art as the signature of man?
DESCRIPTION A: Plato saw art as a copy of a copy.
DESCRIPTION B: Aristotle believed art was a representation of nature.
DESCRIPTION C: John Ruskin famously stated, Art is the signature of man, emphasizing the human element in creation.
DESCRIPTION D: Hegel viewed art as a manifestation of the Spirit.

Questions: 30. Which type of Line is most effective if an artist wants to depict growth, dignity, and height?
DESCRIPTION A: Horizontal lines suggest rest, serenity, and the horizon.
DESCRIPTION B: Diagonal lines suggest movement, instability, and action.
DESCRIPTION C: Jagged or zigzag lines suggest chaos, energy, or danger.
DESCRIPTION D: Vertical lines lead the eye upward, symbolizing power, poise, and stability.

Questions: 31. If a room has many different patterns, colors, and furniture styles, but feels messy rather than eclectic, which principle has the designer failed to apply?
DESCRIPTION A: The room has too much variety; variety is not the problem.
DESCRIPTION B: Harmony is the principle that ties disparate elements together; without it, a room feels chaotic.
DESCRIPTION C: Emphasis might exist, but it won't fix a lack of overall cohesion.
DESCRIPTION D: Scale deals with the size of objects relative to the room, not the messiness of styles.

Questions: 32. An artist is commissioned to create an outdoor mural in a tropical city with high humidity and heavy rain. Which medium should be avoided to ensure longevity?
DESCRIPTION A: Watercolor is water-soluble; moisture and rain would instantly dissolve the pigment.
DESCRIPTION B: Oil is water-resistant, though it may eventually crack; it is more durable than watercolor.
DESCRIPTION C: Mosaics are highly durable and weather-resistant for outdoors.
DESCRIPTION D: Exterior-grade acrylics are commonly used for murals due to their durability and flexibility

Questions: 33. To create a sense of shallow space in a graphic design poster, which technique should be utilized?
A: Overlapping shapes without changing their size or color value.
B: Using a vanishing point with deep diagonal lines.
C: Using bright blue in the background and dark red in the foreground.
D: Drawing a long, winding road that disappears into a mountain.
DESCRIPTION A: This creates a sense of deep, receding space.
DESCRIPTION B: Overlapping provides a minimal sense of front and back without creating an expansive 3D illusion.
DESCRIPTION C: This uses atmospheric color cues which tend to suggest more depth.
DESCRIPTION D: This is a classic example of deep linear perspective.

Questions: 34. Which color harmony uses three to four colors that are adjacent on the color wheel?
DESCRIPTION A: Analogous colors (e.g., Yellow, Yellow-Green, Green) share a common hue and are peaceful to the eye.
DESCRIPTION B: Triadic colors are equally spaced (forming a triangle).
DESCRIPTION C: Complementary colors are opposites.
DESCRIPTION D: Monochromatic uses only one hue with different values.

Questions: 35. What visual phenomenon occurs when you place two Complementary Colors directly next to each other?
A: They blend together to make a neutral grey.
B: They make each other appear more vibrant and intense.
DESCRIPTION A: This only happens when they are mixed as pigments, not when placed side-by-side.
DESCRIPTION B: Opposite colors vibrate against each other, creating maximum visual interest.
DESCRIPTION C: They stand out more than any other combination.
DESCRIPTION D: Monochromatic requires a single hue.

Questions: 36. The "Spoliarium" by Juan Luna is a world-renowned masterpiece. What does its subject matter symbolize in the context of Philippine history?
A: The celebration of Roman athletic victory.
B: The beauty of classical European art styles.
C: The importance of cleaning public arenas.
D: The social and political suffering of Filipinos under Spanish colonial rule.
DESCRIPTION A: While it depicts a Roman basement, it is a scene of defeat and death, not celebration.
DESCRIPTION B: While it uses the Academic style, its symbolism is specifically geared toward the Filipino struggle.
DESCRIPTION C: This is a literal, non-symbolic interpretation of the "spoliarium" (the morgue of the coliseum).
DESCRIPTION D: The fallen gladiators represent the "spoils" or the oppressed state of the Philippines under the colonizers.

Questions: 37. Who is the National Artist known as the Father of Philippine Sculpture" and the creator of the UP Oblation?
DESCRIPTION A: Napoleon Abueva is the "Father of Modern Philippine Sculpture," known for his abstract works.
DESCRIPTION B: Vicente Manansala was a prominent painter known for "Transparent Cubism."
DESCRIPTION C: Juan Luna was primarily a painter, not a sculptor.
DESCRIPTION D: Tolentino was the master of the classical, representational style in Philippine sculpture.

Questions: 38. What is the primary characteristic of Vicente Manansala's Transparent Cubism?
A: It uses glass panels instead of canvas.
B: It breaks subjects into geometric shapes that overlap and remain translucent.
C: It involves painting only invisible objects.
D: It uses very thin, watery oil paint to make the canvas look like a window.
DESCRIPTION A: It is a style of painting on traditional surfaces, not a physical use of glass.
DESCRIPTION B: Unlike European cubism, Manansala’s style allowed the layers to be seen through, maintaining the integrity of the subject.
DESCRIPTION C: The subjects (like vendors or families) are very much visible and central to the work.
DESCRIPTION D: Transparency refers to the visual layers of the composition, not the physical thickness of the paint.

Questions: 39. A furniture maker creates a chair where the legs are made of thin glass and the seat is made of heavy lead. Which principle is being visually and physically violated?
DESCRIPTION A: Proportion deals with the relationship of parts; thin legs for a heavy seat create a visual and physical "top-heavy" imbalance.
DESCRIPTION B: The chair could be symmetrical but still be structurally and visually awkward.
DESCRIPTION C: Radial balance requires elements to radiate from a center, which is not applicable here.
DESCRIPTION D: While the seat is emphasized by its weight, the core design failure is the relationship of the parts.

Questions: 40. The surface quality of a Bila-o that can be felt by the hand is an example of __________.
DESCRIPTION A: Visual texture is "seen" but not felt.
DESCRIPTION B: Implied texture is a synonym for visual texture, where the artist "tricks" the eye.
DESCRIPTION C: Tactile (or Actual) texture is the physical surface you can touch.
DESCRIPTION D: Woven baskets are generally rough or ribbed, not smooth.

Questions: 41. An artist paints a beautiful landscape but signs a different famous artist's name on it to sell it for more money. This is an example of a failure in ________.
DESCRIPTION A: The painting itself might be beautiful, but the act is wrong.
DESCRIPTION B: The artist clearly has skill if they can mimic a famous style.
DESCRIPTION C: This is Forgery or Fraud, which violates the ethical standards of the art world.
DESCRIPTION D: Harmony is a design principle, not a moral one.

Questions: 42. Which art movement is characterized by dream-like imagery, illogical scenes, and a focus on the subconscious mind?
DESCRIPTION A: Realism focuses on the objective, everyday world.
DESCRIPTION B: Surrealism explores the world of dreams and the unreal.
DESCRIPTION C: Impressionism focuses on the effects of light and color on the senses.
DESCRIPTION D: Pop Art focuses on commercial culture and mass media.

Questions: 43. A homeowner wants to create a warm and cozy atmosphere in a large, drafty living room. Which color selection for the walls would be most effective?
DESCRIPTION A: Warm colors are advancing colors that visually bring walls inward, creating intimacy and warmth.
DESCRIPTION B: Pure white reflects all light and can feel impersonal or "clinical" in a large space.
DESCRIPTION C: Light blue is a cool color that recedes, making a large room feel even larger and colder.
DESCRIPTION D: Green is on the cool side of the spectrum and would not contribute to a cozy or warm psychological effect.

Questions: 44. Which National Artist for Visual Arts is famous for his Expressionist style, often depicting angst, suffering, and junk in a distorted, powerful manner?
DESCRIPTION A: Amorsolo is the master of Luminism and idealized rural life.
DESCRIPTION B: BenCab is famous for his "Sabel" series, which focuses on fluid lines and the Filipino identity.
DESCRIPTION C: Botong Francisco is the premier muralist of Philippine history.
DESCRIPTION D: Ang Kiukok’s work is characterized by aggressive lines and a focus on the harsh realities of the human condition.

Questions: 45. If you are decorating a small bedroom with very little natural light, which value of paint would be most appropriate to make the space feel larger?
DESCRIPTION A: High-value (light) colors reflect the maximum amount of light, creating an illusion of open space.
DESCRIPTION B: Mid-values will neither significantly expand nor shrink the room, but in low light, they can look muddy.
DESCRIPTION C: Low-value (dark) colors absorb light, making a small, dim room feel "caved in."
DESCRIPTION D: Charcoal grey will absorb light and contribute to a gloomy atmosphere in a room with no natural light.

Questions: 46. Which tool is used to keep the fabric stretched and taut while working on embroidery designs?
DESCRIPTION A: The embroidery hoop (or tambour) maintains fabric tension for even stitching.
DESCRIPTION B: Crewel refers to a type of needle with a long eye, not a stretching tool.
DESCRIPTION C: A stiletto is a sharp-pointed tool used for poking holes or guiding thread.
DESCRIPTION D: A gauge is used for measuring short distances, not for stretching fabric.

Questions: 47. Why is the "Bullion Stitch" often categorized as one of the most advanced embroidery stitches?
A: It requires the use of two needles simultaneously.
B: It cannot be performed on woven fabrics.
C: Bullion stitches can be made with various thread types, including stranded cotton.
D: It involves complex thread wrapping that must remain consistent in tension.
DESCRIPTION A: Only one needle is used for bullion stitches.
DESCRIPTION B: It is commonly used on woven fabrics for floral designs.
DESCRIPTION C: Bullion stitches can be made with various thread types, including stranded cotton.
DESCRIPTION D: Tension is critical; inconsistent wrapping causes the "caterpillar" effect to look uneven.

Questions: 48. You are preparing a crochet project using a very fine lace thread. Which hook material would be most appropriate to prevent the thread from slipping too easily?
DESCRIPTION A: Plastic hooks are usually for larger, bulky yarns and may not be manufactured in very fine sizes.
DESCRIPTION B: Bamboo hooks have a grip but are rarely thin enough for delicate lace work.
DESCRIPTION C: Steel hooks (often called "thread hooks") are designed specifically for fine lace and crochet threads.
DESCRIPTION D: Aluminum hooks are standard for medium-weight yarns but are often too slippery and thick for lace.

Questions: 49. A smocking project requires the fabric to be gathered into tight, even pleats before decorative stitching. Which stitch is primarily used to secure these pleats in a wave or "zig-zag" pattern?
DESCRIPTION A: Cable stitch creates a solid, rope-like line and is the most basic smocking stitch.
DESCRIPTION B: The Trellis stitch is a decorative smocking stitch that moves diagonally across pleats to form a characteristic wave or zig-zag pattern.
DESCRIPTION C: Stem stitch is used for outlines and lacks the elastic movement of trellis work.
DESCRIPTION D: Honeycomb is a surface stitch that creates a diamond pattern but does not primarily create the "wave" movement.

Questions: 50. Which species of rattan is characterized by its large diameter (above 2 cm) and is the primary choice for furniture framing and heavy structural craft?
DESCRIPTION A: Palasan is the most important commercial rattan in the Philippines, known for its large diameter and strength.
DESCRIPTION B: Limuran is a high-quality rattan but is generally second to Palasan for heavy structural framing.
DESCRIPTION C: Sika is a small-diameter rattan used for weaving and binding.
DESCRIPTION D: Panlis is a very thin rattan used primarily for "wrapping" or finishing furniture joints.

Questions: 51. In Abaca craft, the process of stripping is critical to fiber quality. What is the primary difference between Hand-stripped and Spindle-machine stripped fibers?
DESCRIPTION A: Color is determined by the leaf sheath position (inner vs. outer), not the stripping method.
DESCRIPTION B: Hand-stripping produces finer, softer fibers (Sinamay grade), while machine stripping is faster but often produces coarser fibers.
DESCRIPTION C: Both methods maintain high tensile strength, which is inherent to the Musa textilis.
DESCRIPTION D: Water resistance is a biological property of abaca and is not altered by the stripping method.

Questions: 52. While creating an Origami crane, you are asked to perform a "Reverse Fold." What is the mechanical result of this action on the paper?
A: The paper is folded in half to create a mountain crease.
B: The paper is rolled into a cylindrical shape.
C: The crease is tucked inside the layers of the model.
D: The edges are trimmed to create a symmetrical square.
DESCRIPTION A: A simple fold in half is a valley or mountain fold, not a reverse fold.
DESCRIPTION B: Rolling paper is a technique for quilling, not origami folding.
DESCRIPTION C: An inside or outside reverse fold involves changing the direction of the crease and tucking it within the model’s layers.
DESCRIPTION D: Origami traditionally forbids trimming or cutting the paper.

Questions: 53. If an embroiderer wants to create a 3D, raised texture for a flower petal, which stitch would be the most effective application?
DESCRIPTION A: Bullion stitches involve multiple wraps around a needle to create a raised, worm-like coil, perfect for 3D textures.
DESCRIPTION B: French knots create small dots, which are too small for an entire petal's structure.
DESCRIPTION C: Backstitch is a flat stitch used for outlines.
DESCRIPTION D: Lazy daisy is a flat loop stitch, not inherently 3D or raised.

Questions: 54. In Bamboo craft, why is it necessary to "cure" or treat the bamboo in a chemical solution (like Borax) or by smoking it before production?
A: To make the bamboo more flexible for bending.
B: To change the color of the bamboo to a darker brown.
C: To remove the natural starch that attracts powder-post beetles.
D: o increase the water content of the bamboo culm.
DESCRIPTION A: Flexing is achieved through heat (blowtorch), not curing solutions.
DESCRIPTION B: Smoking may darken the bamboo, but the primary purpose is preservation, not coloration.
DESCRIPTION C: Curing is essential to remove or neutralize the starch/sugar that attracts wood-boring insects.
DESCRIPTION D: Curing aims to reduce moisture to prevent mold and cracking.

Questions: 55. When reading a crochet pattern, the instruction "pull through 2 loops, yo, pull through 2 loops" describes the completion of which stitch?
DESCRIPTION A: Single crochet only requires pulling through two loops once.
DESCRIPTION B: Half double crochet involves pulling through all three loops on the hook at once.
DESCRIPTION C: Double crochet is a "two-step" height stitch where you pull through two loops twice.
DESCRIPTION D: Slip stitch involves pulling the yarn directly through the loop on the hook without an extra yarn-over.

Questions: 56. Which fabric is considered the "gold standard" for smocking because its weave naturally allows for even pleating?
DESCRIPTION A: Denim is too heavy and stiff for the fine gathering required in traditional smocking.
DESCRIPTION B: Gingham’s check pattern provides a natural grid that makes it easy to keep pleats and stitches perfectly aligned.
DESCRIPTION C: Silk Shantung has slubs (irregularities) that make even pleating difficult.
DESCRIPTION D: Organza is too sheer and slippery for beginners to manage the tension required in smocking.

Questions: 57. In Paper Craft, the term "Papier-mâché" literally translates to "chewed paper." Which additive is usually mixed with the paper pulp to ensure the final product is hard and durable?
DESCRIPTION A: Starch or glue acts as the binding agent that hardens the paper fibers as they dry.
DESCRIPTION B: Vinegar is sometimes added in small amounts to prevent mold, but it doesn't provide hardness.
DESCRIPTION C: Glycerin makes materials softer and more flexible, which is the opposite of the goal for papier-mâché.
DESCRIPTION D: Oil paint is a finishing medium, not a structural additive for the pulp.

Questions: 58. A rattan craftsman uses a "blowtorch" during the production phase. What is the primary analytical reason for this step?
A: To burn off the hairs and outer skin of the rattan.
B: o kill any insects living inside the rattan core.
C: To dry the rattan quickly after it has been harvested.
D: To heat the internal resins of the rattan to allow for bending without breaking.
DESCRIPTION A: This is called \scraping or singeing, but the torch’s main structural use is for bending.
DESCRIPTION B: Insect treatment is done via chemical "pickling" or smoking baths.
DESCRIPTION C: Rattan is air-dried or kiln-dried; a blowtorch would be too localized and aggressive for drying.
DESCRIPTION D: Applying heat softens the fibers and resins, allowing the rattan to be bent into furniture shapes.

Questions: 59. In Embroidery, the Pounce" method involves which specific combination of tools?
DESCRIPTION A: This refers to the embroidery process itself, not the design transfer.
DESCRIPTION B: The design is pricked with holes, and charcoal or chalk powder (pounce) is rubbed through them.
DESCRIPTION C: This describes the tracing method.
DESCRIPTION D: This describes modern heat-transfer methods.

Questions: 60. Which part of the Abaca plant yields the strongest and highest quality fiber?
C: The middle leaf sheaths of the trunk
D: The outer leaf sheaths of the trunk
DESCRIPTION A: The roots do not contain extractable craft fibers.
DESCRIPTION B: The leaves are not the source; the fiber comes from the petiole.
DESCRIPTION C: The middle sheaths produce the best balance of strength, length, and color for high-quality crafts.
DESCRIPTION D: The outer sheaths are the toughest and darkest, but often coarser.

Questions: 61. Which of the following crochet hooks is the largest in diameter?
DESCRIPTION A: 10.0 mm (Size N/P) is a jumbo hook used for bulky or T-shirt yarns.
DESCRIPTION B: 3.5 mm is standard for DK-weight yarn.
DESCRIPTION C: 5.0 mm is a medium/large hook for worsted weight.
DESCRIPTION D: 2.5 mm is a fine hook for sport-weight yarn.

Questions: 62. What is "Pyrography" in the context of Bamboo and Wood crafts?
A: The process of soaking bamboo in water.
B: The art of decorating wood/bamboo with burn marks from a heated tool.
C: The method of weaving bamboo strips into mats.
D: he chemical treatment used to prevent rot.
DESCRIPTION A: This is "leaching" or water-curing.
DESCRIPTION B: Pyrography is ]fire-writing, using heat to create designs on the surface.
DESCRIPTION C: This is simply weaving or "sawali making.
DESCRIPTION D: This is preservation or "pickling."

Questions: 63. Which paper type is best suited for "Paper Quilling" due to its ability to hold a coiled shape without tearing?
DESCRIPTION A: Tissue paper is too thin and fragile to hold a coil.
DESCRIPTION B: Construction paper is too fibrous and thick, leading to "cracking" when rolled tightly.
DESCRIPTION C: Newsprint becomes brittle and yellows quickly, making it unsuitable for decorative quilling.
DESCRIPTION D: Quilling strips are specifically weighted to be flexible enough to roll but stiff enough to hold the shape.

Questions: 64. In the Prick and Pounce embroidery transfer method, what tool is traditionally used to prick" the design?
DESCRIPTION A: A fine needle or a specialized pricking tool is used to create the holes for the powder to pass through.
DESCRIPTION B: A thimble protects the finger during sewing.
DESCRIPTION C: Scissors are for cutting thread, not for making tiny uniform holes in paper.
DESCRIPTION D: A stiletto makes holes in fabric for eyelets, which are too large for the pounce method on paper.

Questions: 65. Evaluate the use of "Bolo" in bamboo craft. Which task is the Bolo most specifically suited for?
B: Final sanding and smoothing of the culm surface.
C: Splitting large bamboo culms into workable slats.
DESCRIPTION A: Pyrography requires a heated electric tool or metal rod.
DESCRIPTION B: Sanding is done with sandpaper or a scraper.
DESCRIPTION C: The Bolo is a heavy-duty cutting tool essential for the primary processing and splitting of raw bamboo.
DESCRIPTION D: Measuring is done with a ruler or meter stick.

Questions: 66. Which of the following is a "foundation stitch" in crochet that is used to start almost every project?
DESCRIPTION A: Slip stitch is used to join rows or move yarn, not typically as the primary foundation row.
DESCRIPTION B: The chain stitch forms the base row upon which all other stitches are built.
DESCRIPTION C: Treble crochet is a decorative height stitch.
DESCRIPTION D: Popcorn stitch is a textured cluster stitch.

Questions: 67. When analyzing Rattan, what is the Peel or Skin primarily used for?
C: Filling the internal core of pillows.
D: Weaving the seats and backs of chairs.
DESCRIPTION A: The "pole" or whole stem is used for structural legs.
DESCRIPTION B: Rattan peel is a valuable craft material and not used as agricultural fertilizer.
DESCRIPTION C: Rattan is too hard and sharp for pillow filling.
DESCRIPTION D: The skin is stripped into thin ribbons for intricate "wicker" weaving.

Questions: 68. In Abaca production, what is Sinamay?
A: The raw sap of the abaca plant.
B: A type of abaca specifically used for making ropes.
C: A stiff, loosely woven fabric made from abaca fibers.
D: The machine used to strip the fibers.
DESCRIPTION A: Abaca sap is a waste product, not a craft material.
DESCRIPTION B: Rope is made from Manila Hemp (coarser abaca), not sinamay fabric.
DESCRIPTION C: Sinamay is the most famous textile produced from abaca, used in hats and gift wraps.
DESCRIPTION D: The machine is called a Hagotan or spindle stripper.

Questions: 69. A student wants to make a paper sculpture that is lightweight but very strong. They choose to layer strips of paper soaked in adhesive over a balloon. What is this technique called?
DESCRIPTION A: This describes the layered "strip" method of papier-mâché.
DESCRIPTION B: Decoupage is the art of decorating an object by gluing paper cutouts onto it.
DESCRIPTION C: Origami is folding only; it uses no glue or armatures.
DESCRIPTION D: Quilling involves rolling thin strips into coils.

Questions: 70. Which embroidery stitch is composed of two interlocking rows of slanted stitches and is often used for borders?
DESCRIPTION A: Stem stitch creates a rope-like line, not a crossed interlocking pattern.
DESCRIPTION B: Running stitch is a simple straight line of dashes.
DESCRIPTION C: Cross stitch is an individual X shape, though it can be grouped in rows.
DESCRIPTION D: Herringbone stitch creates a crossed, textured border that looks like a spine.

Questions: 71. In Smocking, the Cable Stitch is considered inelastic. What does this mean for the design of the garment?
A: The garment will stretch easily when the wearer moves.
B: The smocking will hold the fabric firmly in place and limit its stretch.
C: The thread will break if the fabric is pulled.
DESCRIPTION A: Elastic stitches like the honeycomb allow for stretch.
DESCRIPTION B: Inelastic stitches lock the pleats, providing structure but preventing the fabric from expanding.
DESCRIPTION C: Inelastic refers to the movement of the pleats, not the breaking point of the thread.
DESCRIPTION D: Smocking has no effect on the waterproof properties of fabric.

Questions: 72. Which of the following is a characteristic of "Bambusa blumeana" (Kawayan Tinik)?
A: It has a set of thorns at its base branches.
C: It is the smallest bamboo in the Philippines.
D: It cannot be used for construction.
DESCRIPTION A: Kawayan Tinik is identified by the spiny/thorny branches at the lower part of the clump.
DESCRIPTION B: Tinik means thorn; this species is famous for them.
DESCRIPTION C: It is one of the larger and most useful construction bamboos.
DESCRIPTION D: It is the primary bamboo used for building traditional houses (Bahay Kubo).

Questions: 73. What happens if you use a crochet hook that is too small for a very thick yarn?
A: The project will be very loose and draped.
B: The yarn will split and break immediately.
C: The stitches will be extremely tight and the fabric will be stiff.
D: The hook will melt from friction.
DESCRIPTION A: Loose fabric results from a hook that is too large.
DESCRIPTION B: Yarn splitting is usually a result of poor yarn quality or a sharp hook, not just size.
DESCRIPTION C: Small hooks create tight, dense, and rigid fabric when used with thick yarn.
DESCRIPTION D: Friction in crochet does not generate enough heat to melt hooks.

Questions: 74. In Paper Craft, GSM stands for Grams per Square Meter. How does GSM affect a paper craft project?
A: It determines the color of the paper.
B: It tells you the pH level of the paper.
C: It indicates how many sheets are in a pack.
D: It determines the weight and thickness of the paper.
DESCRIPTION A: Color is a chemical/dye property.
DESCRIPTION B: This refers to acid-free properties.
DESCRIPTION C: This is a ream or sheet count.
DESCRIPTION D: Higher GSM means thicker, heavier paper (like cardstock), while lower GSM is thinner (like tissue).

Questions: 75. In Rattan craft, the process of Singeing is used to _________.
A: Bend the rattan into a circle.
B: Remove the fine hairs on the surface of the rattan.
C: Bleach the rattan to make it white.
D: Glue two pieces of rattan together.
DESCRIPTION A: Bending is done through heating the core, not just singeing the surface.
DESCRIPTION B: Singeing involves passing the rattan over a flame quickly to burn off the tiny natural fuzz or hairs.
DESCRIPTION C: Bleaching involves chemicals like hydrogen peroxide.
DESCRIPTION D: Rattan is joined with screws, nails, or weaving, not singeing.

Questions: 76. When transferring an embroidery design using the tracing method, which tool is specifically used to ensure the lines are clean without damaging the fabric?
DESCRIPTION A: Tracing paper is the primary medium used to transfer designs directly onto the fabric surface.
DESCRIPTION B: A stiletto is used for making eyelets or holes in the fabric, not for tracing lines.
DESCRIPTION C: Pounce is a fine powder used in the prick and pounce method, not the tracing method.
DESCRIPTION D: A crewel needle is an embroidery tool for stitching, not for transferring designs.

Questions: 77. Abaca is often called Manila Hemp. Why is this name technically inaccurate?
B: It is only used for food, not for fiber.
C: It is a synthetic fiber, not a natural one.
D: It is not a member of the Hemp (Cannabis) family; it is a member of the Banana family.
DESCRIPTION A: While it grows across the Philippines, the name Manila refers to the port it was shipped from.
DESCRIPTION B: Abaca is primarily a fiber crop; its fruit is non-edible.
DESCRIPTION C: Abaca is a 100% natural leaf fiber.
DESCRIPTION D: Abaca is Musa textilis, a relative of the banana, whereas true hemp is Cannabis sativa.

Questions: 78. In Smocking, Surface Stitches differ from Gathering Stitches in what way?
A: Surface stitches are done on the back; gathering stitches on the front.
B: Surface stitches are purely decorative; gathering stitches hold the pleats in place.
C: Surface stitches use wire; gathering stitches use thread.
DESCRIPTION A: Both are usually visible or worked from the front (except the dots/guide).
DESCRIPTION B: Gathering stitches are the structural "foundation" that creates the pleats, while surface stitches create the pattern.
DESCRIPTION C: Both use embroidery floss or thread.
DESCRIPTION D: They serve distinct structural and aesthetic functions.

Questions: 79. Which of the following is a safety rule when working with Bamboo and Rattan tools?
A: Keep your fingers away from the path of the cutting tool.
B: Use a dull blade to prevent deep cuts.
C: Always cut towards your body for better control.
DESCRIPTION A: Standard safety requires keeping hands clear of the strike zone or cutting path.
DESCRIPTION B: Dull blades require more force and are more likely to slip, causing accidents.
DESCRIPTION C: You should always cut away from your body.
DESCRIPTION D: Eye protection is essential when splitting bamboo or using power tools.

Questions: 80. In Crochet, what is a Magic Ring?
A: A plastic ring you sew into the project.
B: A specialized hook with a light on it.
C: An adjustable loop used to start projects worked in the round
D: A stitch that uses two different colors at once.
DESCRIPTION A: This would be a plastic ring join, not a magic ring.
DESCRIPTION B: That is a lighted crochet hook.
DESCRIPTION C: The magic ring allows the center hole of a circular project to be pulled completely closed.
DESCRIPTION D: This refers to tapestry crochet.

Questions: 81. Which paper craft involves coiling and shaping narrow strips of paper to create intricate designs?
DESCRIPTION A: Origami is folding.
DESCRIPTION B: Kirigami is the art of folding and cutting paper.
DESCRIPTION C: Papier-mâché uses pulp or layered strips.
DESCRIPTION D: Quilling is specifically the art of rolling/coiling paper strips.

Questions: 82. What is the standard number of strands used when embroidery patterns call for "two strands of floss"?
A: 2 individual strands pulled from the 6-strand skein
DESCRIPTION A: You must separate the strands to achieve the desired thickness.
DESCRIPTION B: Standard embroidery floss comes in 6 strands.
DESCRIPTION C: 12 strands would be extremely thick and difficult to pull through fabric.
DESCRIPTION D: While this results in 2 strands, two strands usually implies two separate lengths.

Questions: 83. In Bamboo craft, what is the Internode?
D: The hollow space between two joints.
DESCRIPTION A: The joint is the node.
DESCRIPTION B: The branch is a separate structural appendage.
DESCRIPTION C: The root is the rhizome.
DESCRIPTION D: The internode is the smooth, hollow section between nodes.

Questions: 84. Which rattan grade is typically the highest, indicating no blemishes and a uniform color?
DESCRIPTION A: Grade C has significant blemishes and color irregularities.
DESCRIPTION B: Grade A rattan is the premium export quality, free from scars and uniform in diameter.
DESCRIPTION C: Rejects are materials that cannot be used for standard production.
DESCRIPTION D: Unwashed refers to the processing state, not necessarily the quality grade.

Questions: 85. Why is Satin Stitch often used for filling large areas in embroidery?
A: It uses the least amount of thread.
B: It is the strongest stitch and won't snag.
C: It creates a smooth, silk-like surface that covers the fabric completely.
D: It is only used for making outlines.
DESCRIPTION A: Satin stitch actually uses a lot of thread because it covers both sides of the fabric.
DESCRIPTION B: Parallel rows of satin stitch create a lustrous, solid fill.
DESCRIPTION C: Parallel rows of satin stitch create a lustrous, solid fill.
DESCRIPTION D: Outline stitches include backstitch and stem stitch.

Questions: 86. Which smocking stitch is most similar in appearance to a "Chain Link"?
DESCRIPTION A: When worked in alternating directions, cable stitches resemble a chain link.
DESCRIPTION B: Stem stitch looks like a rope or vine.
DESCRIPTION C: Honeycomb looks like a diamond grid.
DESCRIPTION D: Wave stitch is diagonal and flowing, not link-like.

Questions: 87. In Crochet, what does the term Gauge refer to?
A: The number of stitches and rows per inch.
C: The length of the crochet hook.
D: The weight of the finished project.
DESCRIPTION A: Gauge ensures that the finished item will be the correct size.
DESCRIPTION B: This is the retail cost.
DESCRIPTION C: Hook length is standard; "size" refers to diameter.
DESCRIPTION D: This is simply the project weight.

Questions: 88. When sorting Abaca fibers for high-end textile production, why are fibers taken from the inner leaf sheaths of the stalk valued differently than those from the outer sheaths?
A: They are significantly darker and more weather-resistant.
B: They are the longest fibers but the most difficult to dye.
C: They contain a higher concentration of natural oils that prevent them from drying out.
D: They are whiter, softer, and more lustrous, making them ideal for fine weaving.
DESCRIPTION A: The outer sheaths produce the darkest and toughest fibers, not the inner ones.
DESCRIPTION B: Length is generally consistent throughout the stalk; the primary difference is texture and color.
DESCRIPTION C: Abaca fibers are valued for their cellulose strength, not for oil content, which is actually removed during processing.
DESCRIPTION D: Inner sheaths are protected from the elements, resulting in the high-quality, pale fibers used for Sinamay and fine clothing.

Questions: 89. A crochet pattern requires a stitch that is taller than a Double Crochet. Which technical execution correctly describes the Treble Crochet?
A: Yarn over once, insert hook, and pull through all three loops at once.
B: Yarn over twice, insert hook, and pull through two loops three times.
C: Insert hook into the stitch without a yarn over and pull through both loops.
D: Yarn over three times and pull through all loops in a single motion.
DESCRIPTION A: This describes a Half Double Crochet.
DESCRIPTION B: A Treble Crochet is defined by two yarn overs at the start, creating a taller post by pulling through loops in three stages.
DESCRIPTION C: This describes a Single Crochet.
DESCRIPTION D: Yarn over three times would be a Double Treble, and pulling through all loops at once would not create the necessary height.

Questions: 90. In the post-processing of Rattan, what is the primary purpose of using a Hydrogen Peroxide solution?
A: To soften the rattan poles so they can be bent into furniture frames.
B: To act as a powerful adhesive when joining two rattan stems together.
C: To seal the pores of the rattan to make it completely waterproof for outdoor use.
D: To bleach the material to achieve a uniform, natural-white appearance.
DESCRIPTION A: Softening for bending is achieved through heat (steam or blowtorch), not chemical bleaching agents.
DESCRIPTION B: Hydrogen peroxide is an oxidizer and has no adhesive properties.
DESCRIPTION C: Sealing is done with lacquer, varnish, or wax during the finishing stage.
DESCRIPTION D: Bleaching is a standard industrial step to remove natural stains and create the uniform light color expected in export-quality rattan.
